componenttext: Okay. This is the first time we provided third quarter guidance, specifically. So as we think about the shape of the business, the only thing that's really unique in the third quarter is around M&A, and those activities that I talked about. So we've got a couple of pennies per quarter of dilution coming from the acquisitions. The early focus is around integration, development, et cetera with a real go-to-market push coming late in the year. And so, that's basically it. We also have some one-time transaction costs in Q3 related to those. And that adds another 1 to 2 pennies. So that's the primary Delta.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And obviously that would have been in us nice upside for the full year. Do you think that, that now hold it back, or do you think that there's still be a little bit of margin benefit in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And obviously that would have been in us nice upside for the full year. Do you think that, that now hold it back, or do you think that there's still be a little bit of margin benefit in the fourth quarter?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the margin benefit will be from upside to revenue at this point in time. So right now, our guidance was flat, were full year guidance from where we were last quarter. So essentially, we're absorbing all of the dilution that we've incurr
componenttext: Well, I think that the margin benefit will be from upside to revenue at this point in time. So right now, our guidance was flat, were full year guidance from where we were last quarter. So essentially, we're absorbing all of the dilution that we've incurred. But I wanted to break it out to give people a much clearer picture on the dynamics of the components of the business. As far as upside to that, yes. Some upside in revenue will surely flow through the P&L and provide higher up margin and EPS.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from Israel Hernandez with Barclays Capital.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've heard a lot this quarter about weakness in Europe, financials, the government vertical. Could you maybe talk about what you saw from a linearity perspective, were the deals at the end of the quarter coming in where you thought they would've and you
componenttext: We've heard a lot this quarter about weakness in Europe, financials, the government vertical. Could you maybe talk about what you saw from a linearity perspective, were the deals at the end of the quarter coming in where you thought they would've and you see some push outs of some of the larger transaction, especially given some of your exposures in financials and in the government vertical?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Israel. This is David again. I think that uneven is the best characterization of the EMEA business. Both market, I spent some time in EMEA over the quarter, over the course of the customers and partners and others. This is what I can expect. There's
componenttext: Sure, Israel. This is David again. I think that uneven is the best characterization of the EMEA business. Both market, I spent some time in EMEA over the quarter, over the course of the customers and partners and others. This is what I can expect. There's a number of pressures, whether they're public sector or just confidence pressures that are impacting our ability to close deals. And so, I'd say that the timing of specific transactions is a little bit more challenging in EMEA than it is anyplace else. But that's changed from the last couple of quarters. So really nothing new there. Definitely, some business that slid from Q2 to Q3, some large portion of that, which has already been closed actually. So we're not losing opportunity pipe but actually getting customer to sign off on new capital project. There's a little hesitancy out there. But again, nothing wildly different than what we've seen over the last couple of quarters.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Philip Winslow of Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Philip Winslow of Crdit Suisse.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: A question on the desktop solutions business. Obviously, we have seen a lot of improvement in the trend in XenApp over the past couple of quarters here, going from double-digit declines down 7%, down 5% in terms of license growth. David or Mark, if you co
componenttext: A question on the desktop solutions business. Obviously, we have seen a lot of improvement in the trend in XenApp over the past couple of quarters here, going from double-digit declines down 7%, down 5% in terms of license growth. David or Mark, if you could just want to comment on what changed there, why are you going back to more stabilization in that business? And maybe if you can rationalize that vis-a-vis what we're seeing in XenDesktop?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Phil. I'm not sure that there's a lot of natural equilibrium point that I would talk to. I don't believe that exist. I think it's really more of a function of we're selling the right solution for what the customers projects are and what they're tryi
componenttext: Sure, Phil. I'm not sure that there's a lot of natural equilibrium point that I would talk to. I don't believe that exist. I think it's really more of a function of we're selling the right solution for what the customers projects are and what they're trying to drive. And there are certain dynamics that are going on that I think will raise the visibility and interest around that virtualization. One of those has been the tablet phenomenon. A lot of people are using XenApp to deliver applications to iPads, et cetera. The others are just expanding the delivery of applications in a different context. So a lot of uses for the product, it's a great product, it's huge customer base. So I do think that about this level is stable at this point in time, from a year-over-year growth rate perspective. In terms of the dynamics with XenDesktop, I mean in many cases, there is largely different sale. Customers are looking at Desktop transformation a way to transform, I'd say the whole IT delivery into more of a service. And that's where XenDesktop plays much more directly. The larger deals will tend to be XenDesktop, it's a more strategic product. It's more infrastructure focused. And I think that, that's going to become even more pronounced as we move through the next several quarters.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011

componenttext: And our next question comes from Kirk Materne with Evercore Partners.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess, Mark and David, as you all continue to add to your adhere product roster, I was just curious how to think about sort of the go-to-market shifting more to a direct model as you're adding things like Cloud.com and how that sort of impacts your spen
componenttext: I guess, Mark and David, as you all continue to add to your adhere product roster, I was just curious how to think about sort of the go-to-market shifting more to a direct model as you're adding things like Cloud.com and how that sort of impacts your spending outlook or your hiring outlook for the back half of the year.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Mark. We're definitely spending and investing a lot more in direct cuts kinds of people and processes, including our ability to touch, train, educate, et cetera, SI partners. That gives us more reach and more scale. All of that sort of looks the s
componenttext: This is Mark. We're definitely spending and investing a lot more in direct cuts kinds of people and processes, including our ability to touch, train, educate, et cetera, SI partners. That gives us more reach and more scale. All of that sort of looks the same when it comes to the kind of skills, and kind of how it works from a cost model perspective. And we'll continue to see that play out as we look for new partners to power our cloud platform business, as well as inspire some of these SIs to continue along the trajectory, which have been quite good anyway in terms of these level of engagement. And obviously, in our CSA type partner universe, we're doing so that the 2 things. First, we're focusing on managed partners that actually have a business plan, have a focus on Citrix platform. They're doing quite well. And the second area we're probably deliver more considerable consumable type of solution that are most focused on SMB type customers. So we're looking forward to getting the Citrix brand to the Kaviza SKU and launching that later this year, and start that trajectory.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Ashley with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was going to ask about the SaaS business, some nice acceleration there 19% growth, talked about continuing to see collaboration traction. I wonder if you can give us a little bit more color on the improvement you're seeing there.
componenttext: I was going to ask about the SaaS business, some nice acceleration there 19% growth, talked about continuing to see collaboration traction. I wonder if you can give us a little bit more color on the improvement you're seeing there.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. It comes from a number of different areas. I mean probably the single one is from an international standpoint, we've made a lot of investments there. We've talked of them a lot over the year to be by the footprint and the result is, the inter
componenttext: Sure, Steve. It comes from a number of different areas. I mean probably the single one is from an international standpoint, we've made a lot of investments there. We've talked of them a lot over the year to be by the footprint and the result is, the international component of the mix is now north of 15% where it was the south of 10% a year ago. So that's really been the big push geographically. On a product-by-product basis, the collaboration products, which is the probably general bucket that we put, GoToMeeting family and webinar, et cetera, those have been, and continue to be the growth engine moving north of 30%. A couple of standouts that while small numbers are providing the nice incremental growth has been around GoToTraining, which is a product that we initiated last year, and has been growing nicely, as well as our audio services, which have been a nice incremental growth engine as well. So one of the things that both Mark and I talked about in our prepared comments around HD Faces going live here in the short-term is just continuing to add value and differentiate the products in the marketplace. And one of the things that we believe will allow us to not only attract and retain new customers but also maintain the price points at the right level. And so, all of these things coming together will in all of our business accelerate over the last couple of quarters. Looking into the back half of the year, I guess it's at these levels, maybe even slightly faster is the right way to think about the SaaS business.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Steve, the other thing that I'd add is we've had focus on getting the mobile platforms out there with the right kinds of capabilities, not just sort of triple mobile apps, and that's GoToMyPC, GoToMeeting, it's now available on iPhone as well. GoToManage,
componenttext: Steve, the other thing that I'd add is we've had focus on getting the mobile platforms out there with the right kinds of capabilities, not just sort of triple mobile apps, and that's GoToMyPC, GoToMeeting, it's now available on iPhone as well. GoToManage, which we announced at Synergy, is going to be driver on the mobile side of the formula, which is important to overall business.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brent Thill from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brent Thill from UBS.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: David, just on the deferred revenue, I think we were all looking for a little bit stronger improvement in deferred. And can you just talk through the shape of deferred in the second half of the year? Do you expect a bounce back relative to what you saw th
componenttext: David, just on the deferred revenue, I think we were all looking for a little bit stronger improvement in deferred. And can you just talk through the shape of deferred in the second half of the year? Do you expect a bounce back relative to what you saw this quarter?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, actually I thought this quarter was a pretty strong deferred revenue quarter. It's up north of $40 million, about 3/4 of that coming from the Desktop business, the rest split between online and tech services contract. The second half of the year,  it
componenttext: Yes, actually I thought this quarter was a pretty strong deferred revenue quarter. It's up north of $40 million, about 3/4 of that coming from the Desktop business, the rest split between online and tech services contract. The second half of the year,  it generally moves up even further. So with deferred revenue being up about, let's say about 21% year-on-year, I'd expect at least that rate as we move into the back half of the year. One thing I'd add to that is if you look at the components of deferred revenue, you're seeing the long-term grow faster than the short term. And I think long-term deferred was up, just about 30% on a year-over-year basis. And what's going on there is really a reflection of customers looking at multiyear commitments. And so, we've got more and more customers coming for a term based or a site license type of an engagement with the Citrix. And so, that revenue gets deferred and recognized over a period of time instead of upfront like a traditional license sale. So we're seeing more and more of that as customers are looking at long-term deployments.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a quick clarification on your pipeline. You mentioned record profits, and you've seen like there's maybe timing differences but most dealers in your perspective slipped into Q3 and you expect those deals to close in the later stage contract and you f
componenttext: Just a quick clarification on your pipeline. You mentioned record profits, and you've seen like there's maybe timing differences but most dealers in your perspective slipped into Q3 and you expect those deals to close in the later stage contract and you feel comfortable with.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there's certainly a little bit of that in Q3 and predominantly in Europe, and that's just a reflection of the comments we made earlier.
componenttext: Yes, I think there's certainly a little bit of that in Q3 and predominantly in Europe, and that's just a reflection of the comments we made earlier.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Heather Bellini from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Heather Bellini from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Heather. I'll take the first part of that question and ask Mark to answer about Skype. In terms of defining bookings target, we've never really even guidance on look at what they. Certainly, bookings are growing faster than revenue. I think it will
componenttext: Sure, Heather. I'll take the first part of that question and ask Mark to answer about Skype. In terms of defining bookings target, we've never really even guidance on look at what they. Certainly, bookings are growing faster than revenue. I think it will continue to, especially in the license line. But giving actual guidance on that is just something we haven't done in the past. But I will do is to continue to provide commentary around the shape of deferred and the components of deferred just so everyone understands the dynamics that are actually going on in the business. Because while I wouldn't call a material trend at this point, it's just becoming more and more interesting to watch customers looking for longer-term engagements, more strategic in nature as they think about deployment over a multiyear period. So we'll just provide more commentary on that so that everybody understands.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Heather, regarding your question about Skype, a couple things. First, the shape of Skype's business is primarily consumer focused. And they've had actually a very small SMB and business revenue focus. This is where we had great discussions and an agreemen
componenttext: Heather, regarding your question about Skype, a couple things. First, the shape of Skype's business is primarily consumer focused. And they've had actually a very small SMB and business revenue focus. This is where we had great discussions and an agreement to partner with them to help power the Skype for business platform with GoToMeeting. We don't have insight until Microsoft actually closes the acquisition. We don't have insight on to Microsoft product and strategy plans with Skype. But we're assuming that they're going to seek to actually integrate their technology assets with Skype. And that will create a dynamic, and at least in the enterprise and of the marketplace, that will be place where we haven't played big with GoToMeeting at this point. And at the consumer end, we don't really play there either. So we'll stay focused on SMB, focused on ease-of-use, focused on the value proposition that has gotten us here, and do more integration across our own platform and with third parties as we go into the future. And hopefully, Skype will be one of those platforms that we can integrate with as a potential partnership as opposed head-to-head competition. But we really won't know until Microsoft close the deal and talks with us more directly about their strategy.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Walter Prichard from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Walter Prichard from Citigroup.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just on the license update, one thing that we expected might sort to happen here is you might see license update growth accelerate given XenDesktop I think has a higher maintenance rate than XenApp. I'm just wondering why are I haven't seen and will that
componenttext: Just on the license update, one thing that we expected might sort to happen here is you might see license update growth accelerate given XenDesktop I think has a higher maintenance rate than XenApp. I'm just wondering why are I haven't seen and will that happen this year or beyond?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the license update line is going to be either relatively stable on a year-over-year growth rate basis. And part of what's going on is just the type of deal that I mentioned earlier, as we see more customers looking towards longer-term deals, those
componenttext: I think the license update line is going to be either relatively stable on a year-over-year growth rate basis. And part of what's going on is just the type of deal that I mentioned earlier, as we see more customers looking towards longer-term deals, those have a different lead back profile on them. So it just kind of high single-digit, maybe low double-digit year-over-year growth rate is the right way to be thinking about license updates going forward.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, just on the sort of the business, I'm wondering what you're seeing in the SI direct business versus your classic business and if there's any sort of disparity in growth rate between the 2 channels?
componenttext: And then, just on the sort of the business, I'm wondering what you're seeing in the SI direct business versus your classic business and if there's any sort of disparity in growth rate between the 2 channels?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, In terms of the actual growth rate, the SI  has been a big push for us. And so, the SI contribution has been moving up sharply and SI pipeline moved up very sharply. But those tend to concentrate on the large deals. There may be large deals in what
componenttext: Well, In terms of the actual growth rate, the SI  has been a big push for us. And so, the SI contribution has been moving up sharply and SI pipeline moved up very sharply. But those tend to concentrate on the large deals. There may be large deals in what you'd call our more traditional channel but every deal for an SI tends to be high 5 or high 6 figures, 7 figures, et cetera. And so, the actual closing of those tends to be -- it will bounce around a little bit, a little bit less consistent. But at least that business, from the pipeline standpoint, I think was up 25% sequentially or so. So it's a lot of opportunity out there. The specific timing of close, that's gets a little harder to nail down.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the only thing I would add, Walter, is that a number of our SI partners had really created practices and specific skewed offerings around XenDesktop like CSC with dynamic desktop and with their data service. And so, as they do that, they get a lot
componenttext: I think the only thing I would add, Walter, is that a number of our SI partners had really created practices and specific skewed offerings around XenDesktop like CSC with dynamic desktop and with their data service. And so, as they do that, they get a lot more urgency. And it becomes much more of a rhythm in terms of driving the market as opposed to following the market. And obviously, this is what we've been working on for now, a couple years to help them design, architect and skew these kinds of offerings up, which accounts for the increase in the pipeline and the growth rate we're seeing with SI. So it's all good. We wanted to move faster at this point.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from Bradley Whitt with Gleacher.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you seeing the customers on the VMware pricing changes on the scene and curious whether you're seeing more and then downloads and the type of things.
componenttext: I was wondering if you seeing the customers on the VMware pricing changes on the scene and curious whether you're seeing more and then downloads and the type of things.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have seen an uptick in downloads as well as direct inquiries coming in based upon what they did with their licensing. But we're not head long into the server virtualization space. And obviously, we're doing well with that platform across desktop and ne
componenttext: We have seen an uptick in downloads as well as direct inquiries coming in based upon what they did with their licensing. But we're not head long into the server virtualization space. And obviously, we're doing well with that platform across desktop and networking and now in the cloud platform. But it's not a focused go to market for us. So I'd say probably Microsoft with Hyper-V and system centers probably seen a much bigger uptick. We haven't seen greater interest in XenServer.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tim Klassell with Stifel Nicholas.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tim Klassell with Stifel Nicholas.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Ramshig in for Tim. I want to see if you've seen any improvement in sales cycles now with SMB s now that you have these under your belt, I think in the last earnings call, you talked about SMB kind of being the focus and sales practice kind of bei
componenttext: This is Ramshig in for Tim. I want to see if you've seen any improvement in sales cycles now with SMB s now that you have these under your belt, I think in the last earnings call, you talked about SMB kind of being the focus and sales practice kind of being there sort of uneven. Can we expect Kaviza to shut set of shows in the cycle as well?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We barely have a quarter under our belt with the Kaviza product and without a Citrix brand on it. In terms of SMB and sales cycle there, just the announcement of our acquisition, great credibility and comfort to customers and partners that were looking at
componenttext: We barely have a quarter under our belt with the Kaviza product and without a Citrix brand on it. In terms of SMB and sales cycle there, just the announcement of our acquisition, great credibility and comfort to customers and partners that were looking at the Kaviza solution already. And so, we have nice little uptick in revenue there but not overall material yet. And we'd expect sales cycles on this kind of product through the kind of partners that we have around the road that focus on SMBs to be pretty short actually. But we're yet to get to that part of the process so you have to stay tuned for that. Overall, on the enterprise side, sales cycles really haven't changed materially from over the last couple of quarters. Obviously, we're seeing a full range of those cycles based upon whether a deal in XenApp is sort of incremental at the project level and transaction level, which tend to be very short and/or XenDesktop at the strategic level, which can take 90 to 270 days, just depending upon how big and how strategic a transaction like that is with a big gating factor along the way, being the design architecture of the system itself, migrating applications and that process. So we see a full range of cycles but no material change from last quarter.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have a quick follow. In terms of housekeeping, did you talk about the number of XenDesktop licenses sold and the mix between XenDesktop and XenApp
componenttext: I have a quick follow. In terms of housekeeping, did you talk about the number of XenDesktop licenses sold and the mix between XenDesktop and XenApp

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we didn't. We actually stopped talking about licenses a couple of quarters ago because it became less and less indicative of the business performance because of the trade-off and then name user versus CCU license, et cetera. So we haven't been given o
componenttext: No, we didn't. We actually stopped talking about licenses a couple of quarters ago because it became less and less indicative of the business performance because of the trade-off and then name user versus CCU license, et cetera. So we haven't been given out that for a while. I would say the only thing that's probably you in terms of units and impact on units has been the CCU addition. We launched that last quarter. And it's actually been a pretty big uptick. And in terms of revenue, not units, in terms of revenue, it accounted for nearly 25% of the XenDesktop revenue in the second quarter.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Roche with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Roche with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering, if you could give us a bit more analysis on the quarter. At the margin, it looks like the XenApp is doing better than what most people expected. the XenDesktop grew a little slower than what most people expected. And I look at that t
componenttext: I was just wondering, if you could give us a bit more analysis on the quarter. At the margin, it looks like the XenApp is doing better than what most people expected. the XenDesktop grew a little slower than what most people expected. And I look at that trend in the quarter against your reiteration of the growth rate for the combined best of solutions, and the margin and you'll see an acceleration relative to Q2 levels, it that seems to be a little bit slower growth rate than what most of us might have anticipated. Maybe can you give us some insight as to what might be causing that mixed shift? And also, David, I don't know if I missed it but the real order rates if you can give us a bit color on that, and also if you have any data on seat and production for XenDesktop, that will be great.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ross. In terms of the dynamics, the split between the products, we're running just about half and half right now between XenApp and XenDesktop. And the reason why we haven't guided to an individual components is like we've said, every single quarter
componenttext: Sure, Ross. In terms of the dynamics, the split between the products, we're running just about half and half right now between XenApp and XenDesktop. And the reason why we haven't guided to an individual components is like we've said, every single quarter is we're really focused on selling to customers what makes more sense for what they're trying to do, what they're trying to accomplish and the type of deployment. That said, we certainly have put more focus in the last year or so, selling the broader desktop solution, which includes desktops and apps. And it tends to growth rate of that being significantly larger. But in terms of the way we want to forecast the business going forward, it really does need to be combined with the desktop solutions. And so, there will be quarters, I think, were one gross oil faster than the other but the way to really think about it is on a combined basis. And reiterating our 16% to 18% full year is right in line with what we're seeing. Hopefully, that proves to be conservative at the end of the day. But right now, that's our guidance. That's really the way we're thinking about it. In terms of the individual, some of the activity metrics and just remind everybody that these are pure activity metrics, and should, don't take them with a high level of position. But from a reorder rate, it's been a reorder timeline, it's been pretty consistent. Last quarter was 8 months. So about 8 months after the initial order, customers are coming back for a follow-on. Natural size of the reorder moved up a little bit from last quarter. It's more than 9x. So it's a positive indicator. But again, these are more directional than specific. And in terms of actual seats in production, I'm not sure we have any way to measure that with a high level of specificity. I will say that the renewal rates for XenDesktop continue to be extremely high. And that's one of our best indicators that we have in terms of what has actually being deployed and used. Did I answer your question, Ross?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, you did. Thank you.
componenttext: Yes, you did. Thank you.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit more the drivers there considering the weakness in some other networking type of companies like Riverbed and even in Juniper. And how we should think about the growth rate for NetScaler for the year and of the current trends are
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit more the drivers there considering the weakness in some other networking type of companies like Riverbed and even in Juniper. And how we should think about the growth rate for NetScaler for the year and of the current trends are sustainable?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is David again. It's really growth across the business. I mentioned a bit earlier in terms of the individual drivers. But from the enterprise side, it's breadth of accounts of where we are just being successful in terms of our cost tell moti
componenttext: Michael, this is David again. It's really growth across the business. I mentioned a bit earlier in terms of the individual drivers. But from the enterprise side, it's breadth of accounts of where we are just being successful in terms of our cost tell motion. It's been a priority of the business over the course of the year. And so, we're getting more and more customers that are buying NetScaler either in conjunction with a virtual app, virtual Desktop deployment or just raised visibility that we have into other opportunities for more traditional load-balancing, for example, or app security. So that's kind of one motion that's working well. The other is around our virtual appliances. We've made a big push around the last year around VPX and created virtual instances of many of our technologies and they've been very successful. I mentioned in my comments that they're up about 3x from a year ago which grants a small number but now contributing more and more material component all the time. And the benefit there is that customers are not only deploy the physical hardware. But they're deploying virtual appliances now in more of the, we call the service delivery fabric. But we think about the conjunction with a physical appliance anything to virtual appliance and deployed like an application to your web tier, it just gives you a tremendous flexibility from an overall solution architecture. And so, that's been a driver. And then the third is around just the broader capacity in technology that we've delivered to our higher end appliances that are doing extremely well in the traditional Internet-centric cloud service provider or maybe you could call, it enterprise accounts that are building out data centers to deliver cloud services. So all of those things are very -- we're just very, very strong in Q2. As we look at the second half of the year, we do guide at a total division level. So there's a few moving parts that I talked about earlier, we continue to think that the NetScaler as a standalone will be the majority component of that division. On a year-on-year basis, probably in Q3, it will be down year-on-year from a division because we have a huge Q3 a year ago. So in the mid to high teens from a division. And in Q4, it will be back north of 20% year-on-year growth again. So that's the long answer but the way kind of a little more context on the NetScaler side.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: 2 questions about the Data Center business, again another NetScaler question. Could you give us more color around your comments earlier around the cross-selling effort, maybe just an example of the deal or 2 where something changed in the cross-selling ef
componenttext: 2 questions about the Data Center business, again another NetScaler question. Could you give us more color around your comments earlier around the cross-selling effort, maybe just an example of the deal or 2 where something changed in the cross-selling efforts? And then, the second part of the question on Data Center is on the WAN acceleration piece, can you tell us why it slowed down given that your services business was deployed and it is quite busy and clearly, you've got some nice growth in license. It seems to be a core component of a rollout. Why would that slow down?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll take the second part of the question. I mean, our WAN business is largely related to solutions sale, as customers are rolling out and optimizing the other related technologies for virtual apps, virtual desktops, et cetera. However, we also have large
componenttext: I'll take the second part of the question. I mean, our WAN business is largely related to solutions sale, as customers are rolling out and optimizing the other related technologies for virtual apps, virtual desktops, et cetera. However, we also have large deals that occasionally come in from the government, for example, as was the case in Q2 and Q3 last year. We have a very big pop around department of defense that was doing a specific project. So those things are in the pipeline. They come from time from to time. They're very difficult to forecast exactly when they hit. Don't anticipate any, we didn't anticipate any in Q2 and don't anticipate any in Q2. So that's the context around my commentary on the Branch Repeater business. In terms of the cross-sell motion, it was one of the 5 key focus for our field organization this year, and that was -- it includes everything from just awareness, making sure customers are aware of the capabilities we can deliver in the networking area. It's about demonstrating the benefits that are derived by some of our technology integrations to be able to optimize traffic around the virtual app or virtual desktop deployment. And then, putting in place programs to really package these in a way that customers can acquire them easily. And so, that's been a key play, as we call it in the sales and services organization. And so, I mentioned just anecdotally that in some geos, there's even a couple of countries in EMEA that I visited get more than half of their NetScaler business through cross-sell activities, versus trying to sell into Internet accounts, et cetera. So that's what's going on there. And I think it will continue, and one of the gating factors in our networking business is capacity. We spent a lot of time and effort looking for the right people, both internally and our capacity to train channel partners and make sure that they are proficient and capable to sell our networking products. So a lot of work to do still on that front, but we're pretty excited with the results so we throughout this year.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could comment on your expectations for technical services, which were kind of higher than I modeled. And also, comment on the contribution of NetViewer to the business, particularly in Europe.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment on your expectations for technical services, which were kind of higher than I modeled. And also, comment on the contribution of NetViewer to the business, particularly in Europe.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. On tech services, yes, we had a great quarter in tech services, up north of 30%, driven by record utilization of consulting, big support contracts, et cetera. So just strength across all, those line items. I do think that for Q3, it will be flat seq
componenttext: Sure. On tech services, yes, we had a great quarter in tech services, up north of 30%, driven by record utilization of consulting, big support contracts, et cetera. So just strength across all, those line items. I do think that for Q3, it will be flat sequentially, in terms of actual dollars, which will yield a slightly lower year-over-year growth rate that's just based on our capacity. What we're seeing right now, as we add more people and more capacity, we'll be able to ramp that further. But that's the way to think about it right now. From a full year standpoint, I would expect a growth rate in the high 20% range, maybe 30% for the tech services business.

componenttext: I actually don't have the numbers in front of me, because we've integrated that business right out of the gate. But it's certainly one of the driving factors behind the growth in our international business. The strategy of the acquisition was to bring in more capacity, and that's certainly been successful. So we are working through that right now, and I'd equate that to a large part of the growth internationally.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we're real happy with how that team is doing both at leadership level, at the go-to-market level and technology level because we did acquire a number of really sharp developers there. And if you remember, late last year, we started delivering the Fren
componenttext: And we're real happy with how that team is doing both at leadership level, at the go-to-market level and technology level because we did acquire a number of really sharp developers there. And if you remember, late last year, we started delivering the French and German localized versions of GoToMeeting, GoToAssist, et cetera, and then the NetViewer team came in at the back of that giving us a sales team. And we're just barely 2 quarters into it, and really pleased with how they've come up to speed, learning how to sell GoToMeeting, which was a new sales process for them. So they've been focused on selling remote support solutions and how they transitioned over to the GoToAssist platform. So it's a great story of great innovation, a lot of great results coming from end to end.

componenttext: If I could, there's been a lot of questions, I guess around what percentage of your business comes from direct versus indirect channels. And from what I understand, you've been investing a lot in direct, but those folks still comes from a lot of the channel. Is there an appropriate way to look at that just to clarify with inventors rate?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't think there's a specific percentage, and part of the reason for that is business, if you assume that every large transaction, and you can measure that, let's say $100,000 and up, has direct touch to it in some way. And so, it may be built through
componenttext: I don't think there's a specific percentage, and part of the reason for that is business, if you assume that every large transaction, and you can measure that, let's say $100,000 and up, has direct touch to it in some way. And so, it may be built through a partner, a partner maybe participating alongside of us, but we're engaged at some level. And that's changed let's say over 5 years. So more and more business is going through partners like Sis and others that are driving a large part of the actual demand generation, the implementation, et cetera. But we probably have direct touch on more than 2/3 of our business.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And do you have any idea what that might have been a couple years ago?
componenttext: And do you have any idea what that might have been a couple years ago?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: It may be probably be less, but I don't have the specific numbers but that moving it into the right. And that's right in line with the strategic nature of what we are selling now. And as we sell more infrastructure like products, those require the vendor
componenttext: It may be probably be less, but I don't have the specific numbers but that moving it into the right. And that's right in line with the strategic nature of what we are selling now. And as we sell more infrastructure like products, those require the vendor to be closer to the customer. They tend to be much larger deals, more strategic in nature, a less of a project-based sale, which is how I would generalize XenApp 5 years ago. So this has been a continuum. That's been shifting over this period of time, and it will probably continue in this direction.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Curits, I'd say it probably started to tick up maybe 6 or 7 years ago when XenApp started to become more of a strategic kind of product for certain customer segments. And then after we did the NetScaler acquisition, that really required a specialty that o
componenttext: Curits, I'd say it probably started to tick up maybe 6 or 7 years ago when XenApp started to become more of a strategic kind of product for certain customer segments. And then after we did the NetScaler acquisition, that really required a specialty that our channel organization did not have at the time. And then, probably another inflection point, a couple years ago now when XenDesktop went strategic and where we really understood the need to talk to customers, larger ones on the direct touch bases when we started to bring SIs and when we went to a more of a managed partner program with our platinum partners and some of our top-tier gold partners. So I'd say it has been gradual taken a bit of an inflection point a couple years ago when XenDesktop began to hit the market has and continues to go that same direction. The acquisition of Cloud.com will continue that trajectory because the kind of sales passes and direct engagement even after the sale, whether it's on architecture or implementation support, is much more profound than let say than either event XenDesktop at this stage of customer and market maturity. So we're investing a lot in professional services, ERMs, technical relationship managers and the people that really build our SI partnerships, including those that trained them. We have a huge uptick in trainings and so forth. So a lot of energy going into that.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Chuck, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Citrix Systems Second Quarter 2011 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to intr
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Chuck, and I will be your conference facilitator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Citrix Systems Second Quarter 2011 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Mr. Eduardo Fleites, Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr.  Fleites, you may begin your conference.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chuck. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for today's call where we will be discussing Citrix's second quarter 2011 financial results. Participating in the call will be Mark Templeton, President and Chief Executive Officer;
componenttext:
Thank you, Chuck. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for today's call where we will be discussing Citrix's second quarter 2011 financial results. Participating in the call will be Mark Templeton, President and Chief Executive Officer; and David Henshall, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. This call is being webcast with a slide presentation on the Citrix Systems Investor Relations website. And the slide presentation associated with the webcast will be posted immediately following the call.
Before we begin the review of our financial results, I want to state that we have posted product classification and historical revenue trends related to our product groupings to the Investor Relations page of our website. I would like to remind you that today's conversation will contain forward-looking statements made under the Safe Harbor provisions of the U.S. Securities laws. These statements are based on current expectations and assumptions that are subject to risks and uncertainties, such as the impact of the global economic climate, uncertainty in the IT spending environment, risks associated with our products, acquisitions and competition. Obviously, these risks could cause actual results to differ from those anticipated.
Additional information concerning these and other factors is highlighted in today's press release and in the company's filings with the SEC, including the risk factor disclosure contained in our most recent annual report on Form 10-K, which is available from the SEC or on the company's Investor Relations website.
Furthermore, we will discuss various non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC's Reg G. A reconciliation of the differences between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures, discussed on today's call, can be found at the end of today's press release and on the Investor Relations page of our website.
Now I would like to turn it over to David Henshall, our Chief Financial Officer. David?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eduardo, and welcome to everyone joining us this afternoon. In Q2, we delivered a record $531 million in total revenue, adjusted EPS of $0.57 and $162 million in cash flow from operations. We're continuing to drive leadership across Desktop Virt
componenttext:
Thanks, Eduardo, and welcome to everyone joining us this afternoon. In Q2, we delivered a record $531 million in total revenue, adjusted EPS of $0.57 and $162 million in cash flow from operations. 
We're continuing to drive leadership across Desktop Virtualization, delivering significant new technologies in cloud networking and expanding the capabilities and footprint in our SaaS business, trends that can be clearly seen in our business results. 
So looking at the second quarter, revenue from new license sales was $171 million, up 15% from last year. License update revenue increased 9%. Technical services increased 33%, led by record consulting demand and support agreements. And our SaaS revenue was $106 million, up 19%. 
From a geographic perspective, the Americas region continues to execute really well, delivering revenue up 16% from last year to $235 million. Included in this number are 17 individual transactions greater than $1 million each.  In EMEA, revenue was up 9% to $136 million. And similar to Q1, demand was uneven across the region, particularly within the public sector as many countries as still working through budgetary constraints and capital project prioritization.  And finally, revenue in Japan and Pacific continues to grow very significantly, posting the combined growth of 31% from last year.
So overall, a really solid quarter. As we start the second half of 2011, customer activity metrics and pipeline are record levels. We remained committed to delivering strong results, integrating our recent acquisitions and expanding our competitive position across our main product groupings. 
So, now let's look at the Q2 results within these 3 businesses. First, overall, Desktop solutions grew 9% from last year to nearly $305 million, including product license revenue growth of 10%. So for the first half of 2011, license revenue in this business is up 15%. And consistent with my prior comments, we do anticipate accelerating year-over-year growth in the back half, which should lead to 16% to 18% product license increase for the full year.
Our license growth here continues to be led by the strength in XenDesktop. During Q2, sales of XenApp products were flat year-on-year, while XenDesktop license was up more than 20%. And as you recall, in Q2 of last year, we had a really successful desktop Trade-up promotion that skewed the year-over-year license comps. So if you look at the individual sales motions, license revenue coming through the desktop Trade-up was down about 1/3 from last year, while revenue generated from new XD licenses grew by over 65% in the period.
For a little more context on the Desktop solutions business in Q2, there's a few metrics that really demonstrate the breadth of adoption we're seeing and the strategic value that customers are placing on Desktop Virtualization within their infrastructure. In fact, there were 10 $1 million plus deals in Q2 for XenDesktop, representing customers from multiple industries, including telecommunications, media, government, education and services with a few of these customers actually choosing to engage on the basis of a multiyear site license.
In total, there were over 2,800 different customers that purchased XenDesktop in the period, including 163 transactions for more than 1,000 seats each and 19 deals for over 5,000 seats each. And we exit in Q2 with a record pipeline in total and for those deals over $1 million.
So next, in our Data Center and Cloud business. Total revenue was over $90 million, up 32% in the quarter with new product revenue increasing 26%. Growth in this business was led by the NetScaler product line with license revenue up 90% year-on-year. 
And the strength in NetScaler in Q2 is really coming from a number of different areas. First, we continue to see traction driving the cross-sell motion into our traditional enterprise account base. In fact, more than half of NetScaler customers in Q2 were first-time NetScaler buyers. Second, contribution from the VPX line of virtual appliances nearly tripled from a year ago as customers are recognizing the value of deploying the virtual and physical appliances together as a complete solution.  Third, the new NetScaler SDX platform, which enables customers to run numerous virtualized NetScaler instances with full multitenant support began shipping in late June, and has already generated 10 new customers.  And finally, we just had a record quarter from Internet-centric businesses and customers building out the infrastructure to support large cloud-based services.
And offsetting the very strong growth in NetScaler, licenses for our WAN op solution, Branch Repeater, declined by about 2/3 from Q2 a year ago. And as you know, historically, comparisons in our WAN op business were occasionally skewed by large individual orders as was the case in Q2 and Q3 of 2010.
So finally, turning to the SaaS business, revenue was up 19% in the second quarter to $106 million. The growth continues to be led by our collaboration products, which were up 31% and now account for over half of our total SaaS revenue. SaaS will further value through collaborations. This quarter, we're releasing in HDFaces, the videoconferencing capabilities is fully integrated into GoToMeeting. 
Geographically, the investments we've been making to expand this business internationally have been delivering results. In Q2, revenue from our international markets accounted for about 15% of the total, which is up from less than 10% a year ago.
So looking at expenses and operations now. In Q2, adjusted op margin was 25%, an increase of about 1.5 points over Q1 and a result of our revenue performance. Our plan has been to invest slightly behind demand growth that we're seeing in the market. So as bookings, pipeline and POCs have accelerated, we continue to focus on 2 main areas. 
The first is expanding go-to-market reach and customer touch through enterprise account managers, strategic partnerships, consulting and tech support. The second area is product innovation to bring to market new technologies, as well as improving integration across the solutions to drive simplicity and better end-user experience.
In Q2, we added 130 new people to Citrix, primarily in the sales and the services in the SaaS business. Headcount now stands at over 6,100 employees, which is an increase of about 1,000 people as compared to the same period of last year. And also of note, cost of goods sold as a percentage of revenue increased both sequentially and year-on-year. And the primary driver here is product license mix due to the very strong NetScaler results, as well as the record demand for consulting services.
Turning to the balance sheet. Cash and investments totaled $1.7 billion, driven by $162 million in cash flow from operations. On a trailing 12-month basis, cash flow from ops is over $690 million, an increase of 24% year-on-year over the comparable period. During the quarter, we repurchased nearly 1.2 million shares of stock. And we also spent about $30 million on M&A and licensing activity. 
Deferred revenue at the end of the quarter was a record $830 million, up $41 million sequentially, and up 21% from a year ago. The main drivers around deferred revenue have been the increasing number of customers, XenDesktop customers in the subscription advantage program, the number of customers that have been initiating multiyear agreements and tech services contracts for consulting, maintenance and support.
So really in summary, we continue to execute well. We're seeing growth in all of our strategic businesses. And we're making investments necessary to extend our leadership position in critical markets while expanding go-to-market capacity.
So before I get to guidance, I'd like to briefly discuss the financial impact of our recent acquisitions, Kaviza and Cloud.com. Both of these companies bring great technology and future opportunity to Citrix but are in their early stages of ramping their revenue base. Our plan is to initially focus on development and integration with the majority of go-to-market activities happening later in the year. Therefore, these acquisitions will result in aggregate EPS dilution of about $0.03 in Q3 and an additional $0.02 in Q4. This dilution is included in our forward-looking guidance.
So given the strength that we're seeing across several facets of the business and the growth in our opportunity pipeline, we're increasing our revenue outlook for 2011. For the full year, our current expectations are now for total revenue to be in the range of $2.16 billion to $2.19 billion, and adjusted EPS to be in the range of $2.38 to $2.41 per share. And for the third quarter of 2011, we currently expect total revenue to be in the range of $540 million to $547 million; adjusted tax rate, between 22% and 23%; and adjusted EPS between $0.56 and $0.58.
So now I'd like to turn it over to Mark to give you additional details on the quarter's performance and discuss our ongoing businesses. Mark?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks much, David. I'm really pleased with our Q2 performance and proud of the strategic and financial results we've delivered this year. We have great confidence in our execution and growth in all 3 of our focal markets. Customer enthusiasm for going vi
componenttext:
Thanks much, David. I'm really pleased with our Q2 performance and proud of the strategic and financial results we've delivered this year. We have great confidence in our execution and growth in all 3 of our focal markets. Customer enthusiasm for going virtual across meetings, desktops and clouds is simply amazing. 
We saw this firsthand in our Synergy San Francisco conference, which was completely sold out again. Since the conference, I spent significant time with enterprise customers, with SI partners and service providers in the U.S., Europe and Asia. These conversations have consistently focused on 3 key things: the massive impact of consumerization, the transformation of IT to on-demand delivery, and the allure of external cloud services.
We think these are the conversations of the post-PC era, setting the stage for the cloud era, where customers are focused on 3 things: building new clouds, connecting to existing cloud services and empowering people and business to work in new ways.
So next, I'd like to highlight each of these areas. The transition from the PC era to the cloud era is fueling a massive buildout in cloud infrastructure. This market will feature thousands of providers of all shapes and sizes, offering a vast array of new cloud services, services that range from business, infrastructure and development offerings to consumer, mobile and gaming. It will also feature thousands of enterprise customers seeking to transform their existing data centers from rigid cost centers into more elastic private clouds, designed to deliver desktops and apps as a service. This buildout is driving great demand for our cloud networking products and positioning us well for growth in the new cloud platforms business we acquired with Cloud.com.
Let's talk first about cloud networking. Every cloud, public or private, need the next-generation networking system at the core, ensuring scalable performance, reliability and security. This is fueling strong growth in NetScaler, based on our ability to be weave virtualization into the core fabric of cloud networking. This differentiation is paying off in all 3 of our NetScaler platforms, MPX, VPX and the new SDX. 
NetScaler MPX continues to be the centerpiece of our lineup, a standard for the world's largest .coms and web 2.0 providers and delivering the industry's best price performance ratio for enterprises. Cross-selling with XenDesktop has been a significant driver of MPX growth.  In addition, we're winning new customers with our powerful DataStream technology that offloads and balances sequel databases. 
NetScaler VPX, our fully virtualized cloud networking system is also seeing significant traction. We now have over 1,500 customers in production on NetScaler VPX software appliances. More than 80% were first-time NetScaler customers, making VPX a great cross-sale, an easier way to expand our customer base and a potent competitive weapon. In fact, more than 25% of NetScaler customers are now running a mix of MPX and VPX systems, realizing the power of NetScaler as a service delivery fabric.
As David mentioned, SDX is seeing great early adoption, designed as a multitenant backbone for cloud services, SDX is built with embedded XenServer technology, optimized for network IO, allowing it to run up to 40 virtual NetScaler instances simultaneously in the same appliance, all while delivering wire-speed performance and a stunning 50-gig throughput. This powerful combination of NetScaler MPX, VPX and SDX puts us in great position for the buildout of public and private clouds. And it's an area where we'll build out additional muscle in the second half of the year.
This quarter, we also announced the acquisition of Cloud.com, creators of the market-leading CloudStack platform, enabling simple cost-effective cloud services that are scalable, secure and open by design. This will significantly accelerate the Olympus project we announced during Synergy, a project based on OpenStack, the popular open-source cloud movement. 
Cloud.com was a founding member of OpenStack, offering a complementary product for cloud orchestration and administration called CloudStack. CloudStack is hypervisor agnostic and designed for building cloud that are simple, automated, elastic, scalable and massively efficient. 
Cloud.com customers roll out new cloud services up to 50x faster at 1/5 of the cost of alternative solutions. This has yielded impressive early success, with deployments in over 60 large-scale production clouds, including some of the most innovative brands in the world like Zynga, Go Daddy, Tata, Korea Telecom and Nokia.
Overall, the strategy is to offer Citrix's service providers a powerful and open system that delivers a range of profitable on-demand services, like powerful infrastructure as a service, like services based on Citrix technologies including XenApp, VPX, Cloud Bridge and Cloud Gateway, like services based on the OpenStack ecosystem and of course, innovative cloud services of our service providers own design. 
In the second half, we'll focus on smooth integration while gaining additional design wins around the world with key service providers. We'll also accelerate the investment both companies have already made in multi-hypervisor support, as well as our mutual commitment to OpenStack. We're really excited to be joining forces with an incredibly talented Cloud.com team that includes some of the world's most experienced cloud-computing experts. 
As analysts are projecting the cloud infrastructure and services market to exceed $11 billion by the end of 2013, expanding our position now provides us with a tremendous opportunity to accelerate our cloud strategy and formally establish Citrix as a leader in this market.
Committing enterprise customers to these external clouds is an opportunity Citrix is uniquely positioned to lead at both higher-level application layers, as well as infrastructure as a service levels. We are addressing this market with 2 powerful new products. The first is NetScaler Cloud Gateway, which sits at the front door of the enterprise data center, giving IT an easy, unified way to orchestrate the delivery of any mix of SaaS, web and Windows' apps to end users. 
Cloud Gateway unifies silos of private and public cloud apps and provides a single way to manage secure access, user provisioning, license measurement and user experience. And that gives end users a brilliantly easy way to access all their apps, with a single one-time login regardless of what device they are using or where all those apps are being hosted.
The other important connection to cloud services is at the infrastructure layer. Our new NetScaler Cloud Bridge sits at the back door of enterprise data centers, creating a secure, fast, transparent network bridge to virtually any cloud like RackSpace, Amazon, SoftLayer and others. In fact, Cloud Bridge gives private clouds infinite reach to public cloud compute, network and storage resources, things like app testing, vaster recovery, burst over or building new apps. 
As the industry shifts from the PC era to the cloud era, IT is rapidly outgrowing its ability to own and manage all of its own apps, all of its own infrastructure and thousands and thousands of devices. The introduction of Cloud Gateway and Cloud Bridge give IT organizations an easy way to extend their data centers to a vast array of cloud services that are outside their own domain.
Empowering people through a flexible virtual workstyle is the third dimension of enabling the cloud era. It's clear that computing has gone personal again, freeing people to do whatever, whenever, wherever. This mindset of empowerment through mobility, device independence and a work-anywhere experience continues to be the driver of both our Desktop Virtualization and web collaboration businesses. 
It's been said in quarters, since we launched XenDesktop with FlexCast technology, giving customers a single solution that delivers any mix of virtual desktops and apps in one enterprise class product. It's now available with a choice of licensing models and a smooth trade-up path from XenApp. XenDesktop continues to lead the Desktop Virtualization market, winning an impressive array of reviews, awards and market share assessments. 
Earlier this month, IDC added to this growing list by publishing the first-ever report on the desktop virtualization space, report that named Citrix as the only company in the leader category. We are honored, but in a market this early, we still see a lot of space for growth, innovation and expansion. This is why driving primary demand remains our strategic focus. By our estimates, we're still in the early stages of the desktop virtualization market, with tremendous upside still ahead.
From an adoption standpoint, the primary verticals continue to be finance and banking, gov and education and healthcare, driven by the demand for better security and control, lower operational costs and higher business agility. Gradually, we're seeing customers focus on a broader set of strategic business initiatives with XenDesktop, making deals bigger and driving a greater mix across our products. 
Indiana University, for example, is going virtual for over 100,000 students, faculty and staff, with an on-demand personal cloud service called IU anywhere, all powered by XenDesktop. They're lowering support costs, supporting a wide variety of consumer devices and enabling better work life balance for everyone.
At the other end of the spectrum, our corporate customers Suncorp, one of Australia's largest insurance firms, they are deploying 15,000 seats as part of a joint Citrix Microsoft solution, driven by a key corporate initiative to attract, develop and inspire innovation and ingenuity in their workforce by creating a smarter workplace that incorporates hot desking, work from home and employee-owned devices.  These and many others represent a tremendous opportunity ahead as Desktop Virtualization continues toward mainstream. 
We are aggressively driving the evolution of this market with innovations that make going virtual at the desktop easier, more affordable and more accessible to millions of new users and devices. For example, in our latest releases of XenDesktop, XenApp and XenClient, we added new capabilities that reduce the cost of VDI storage up to 50% with our groundbreaking Intellicast technology, features that extend our reach to more than 1 billion end-user devices with new versions of Citrix Receiver, new XenClient technology that support a much broader range of new laptop models and the all-new XenClient XT edition that opens brand-new opportunity and new high-security desktop computing markets.
Breadth is the other key to driving primary demand, expanding the market to broadly serve the SMB customer. Our recent acquisition of Kaviza gives us a simple all-in-one VDI solution, perfect for the SMB. Kaviza's VDI-in-a-box rivals the acquisition cost of a traditional PC, and can be deployed and managed without an enterprise IT department. We think it will really invigorate our SMB-focused partners. 
For product innovation to market expansion, we're relentlessly focused on extending our lead in desktop virtualization as we work to drive broad mainstream adoption. So we're staying on offense, and encourage you to watch this space for some great announcements in the second half.
Empowering users is also about making it easy to collaborate with others. That's what drives our online collaboration business, enabling customers of all sizes to deliver a more virtual work style, one that frees people to work from anywhere with anyone on any device. We're taking that experience to a new level this quarter, with the delivery of GoToMeeting with HDFaces, a stunning solution that brings realtime HD videoconferencing to online meetings at no extra charge to GoToMeeting subscribers. 
HDFaces is brilliantly easy, totally immersive, simply amazing. It delivers tele-presence for everyone in any location without spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on expensive hardware-based systems. And because it's a built-in feature of GoToMeeting, customers get a fully integrated web, audio and video experience, all with the same market-leading ease of use that's always been a hallmark of our SaaS product. 
Looking forward, we'll continue to expand into new markets like IT services with our new GoToManage product line into new geographies in Europe and Asia and to more mobile platforms, building on our top 10 ranking on the iPad with support for an array of exciting new devices.
So now, to wrap up. Our long focus on products that power virtual work styles and cloud services has put us at the center of exciting growth markets, with the opportunity to lead customers as they build clouds, connect to cloud services and empower people. 
Computing, as we've known it, is facing seriously disruptive forces, creating unprecedented stress on today's industry leaders, forcing IT into transformation mode and providing massive opportunity for agile players like Citrix.
So now, I'd like to open it up for questions.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Our first question comes from Adam Holt with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Our first question comes from Adam Holt with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess I had a two-part question about the commentary around the Desktop license accelerating in the back half. First, would you expect XenApp to remain roughly flat on a year-on-year basis? And secondly, if so, that would imply, it looks like, quick cal
componenttext: I guess I had a two-part question about the commentary around the Desktop license accelerating in the back half. First, would you expect XenApp to remain roughly flat on a year-on-year basis? And secondly, if so, that would imply, it looks like, quick calculations, better than 30% growth in XenDesktop license in the back half. Can you maybe walk us through what gives you comfort in that acceleration albeit a tough comp in Q2  but acceleration nonetheless?

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Adam. This is David. Yes, I think you hit it right about down the middle in terms of XenApp as a stand-alone product. And remember, it is fairly hard to forecast exactly the mix that's going to come out because we're showing the customers and what m
componenttext: Sure, Adam. This is David. Yes, I think you hit it right about down the middle in terms of XenApp as a stand-alone product. And remember, it is fairly hard to forecast exactly the mix that's going to come out because we're showing the customers and what makes most sense for the projects that they're looking to deploy. But in order of magnitude, I do think that XenApp, roughly flat year-on-year, is the way to think about it. And then the majority of the growth continuing to come from new licenses of XenDesktop. So we've made Trade-up a part of the ongoing motion, just giving customers a path to migrate from XenApp to XenDesktop, as they looked to a kind of a much more broad, holistic solution around desktops and apps. And then, new licenses is we're either selling into new parts of existing customers or more likely just brand-new customers. So that business is where I think the majority of the growth is going to come from. And what gives us confidence in the growth rates that I talked about here is it's really a function of just the overall opportunity pipeline we're seeing. We're exiting Q2 with record levels across aggregate pipeline and in large deals that I mentioned earlier. We're seeing very high pipeline coverage ratios. We're seeing an increase in activity metrics from our SIs and other partners. And in some of the other metrics that we occasionally quote around that business, be it reorder rates or time to reorder, they're all very positive. And the last comment I'll make is really around the utilization we're seeing for consulting. It's been several quarters in a row now that we've talked about record consulting utilization, and that continues to be the case. It outstrips our capacity by far. And that's really just customers working through everything from proof of concepts up through scaling large deployments. And how successful we are making them successful drives long-term business. So these are all generally moving in the right direction. We feel good that our standing guidance of 16% to 18% growth for this total desktop and app business is the right place right now. We feel very good about that.

componenttext: Following on Adam's question, so if you look at 30% kind of Desktop license growth in the back half, you saw 20% here against a really tough compare, 30% actually seems a little conservative I guess if we were to normalize Q2 of the year ago, maybe you can elaborate on that a little bit.

headline: Citrix Systems, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we always hope guidance proves to be conservative in hindsight. And we do look at this in the context of an emerging business, all the great metrics that I just talked about, and also, an environment that is still a bit on EBIT. I mentioned EMEA gro
componenttext: Well, we always hope guidance proves to be conservative in hindsight. And we do look at this in the context of an emerging business, all the great metrics that I just talked about, and also, an environment that is still a bit on EBIT. I mentioned EMEA growing 9% versus the other geos that are growing between 2 and 3x that fast. And so there's a little bit of that factored in, just continued expectations around the environment. But overall, I do think that the XenDesktop business accelerates in the back half of the year. We did talk about some of the kind of macro-dynamics that are affecting this, in terms of the investments that we've made to make the products easier to acquire, POC scale and manage to improve the ROI profile, those types of things, as well as just the breadth of adoption we're seeing across verticals. Three or 4 quarters ago, we'd be talking about financial services exclusively. Now we're talking about government, education, retail, and others that are really adopting on large scale.
